intro: Synaedrys nariakii, commonly known as the Nariakii mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of specific host trees, primarily in the rainforests of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its small, leathery leaves and white, fleshy berries that contain toxic seeds. The plant derives some of its nutrients from its host through specialized root structures called haustoria, while also performing photosynthesis. It plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its habitat by influencing host tree growth and providing food for certain bird species. Due to habitat loss, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
